Yeah like Chad said, stabilization is not something I'd use for 
memory tasks.  One hack to consider is that if you know exactly what 
prior activations you need in memory you can just have them be 
inputs, as in a sliding window of past activations.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> Bull,
> Maybe you missed the recent flurry of e-mails over the memory 
topic.
> That is my current focus ( but I loved finding 27 e-mails in my box
> about computation time, goods everybody ).
> My first impulse to your question is to say: don't stabalize!
> Stabalizing is a method to destroy memory information by repeatedly
> inputing the current state, and waiting until that input 
propigates the
> network. So, yes, the network "forgets" previous states.
> Allow the recurrent connections to be 'unstable.' This may not seem
> sane, but remember, you can assume a network will behave robustly 
when
> you finish training it. If you train it to play a game, and memory 
has
> an effect on it's fitness, you will most likely develop memory 
through
> recurrent connections that don't behave well when you ask them to 
do
> something else, like repeatedly giving it the same gamestate, 
which is
> what stabalization does. Stabalization could be a usefull tool to
> improve fitness in a game where for each arangment of the board, 
there
> is one best next move. An example might be the little triangle 
pegboards
> where you jump pegs until only one peg is left. Competitive games
> usually don't have a single best move.
> 
> That's my take.
> chad
> 
> <-----Original Message-----> 
> From: Robert Winkel

> I've got another question regarding network stabilization.
> 
> I am trying an experiment where memory is important.
> So, if I allow my network to stabilize, does this mean that
> it has "forgotten" past activations? If so, what approach
> should I take with relaxation? Set a specific depth? The
> in-built depth calculation routines are fairly pointless since
> memory implies recurrency and therefore any viable network
> will cause it to infinitely loop (well, up to a depth of 100)
> and always output 10.
> 
> Say I wanted to do something like evolve networks to play
> a game which required a memory of the previous 5 activations
> in order for it to play well. Would a good relaxation value be
> 5? 6? Or is there a smarter way to approach this?
> 
> Cheers,
> Bull.
